newsitem.title: GERMANY: German debt, futures appear steady on firm footing.
newsitem.headline: German debt, futures appear steady on firm footing.

text.p: German Bunds and futures were steady in late dealings on Thursday and appeared to have firm footing as September Bund futures targeted 103.00.
Stable U.S. debt markets also helped to underpin market sentiment, which was cautious in morning dealings despite weakness in the mark.
But German debt was underperforming the U.S. market due to the weak currency amid some fears German debt prices could quickly fall in any sign of a correction in the U.S. market.
At 1515 GMT, DTB September Bund futures were up 38 basis points at 102.80.
The 10-year 6.00 percent cash Bund due July 2007 was at 103.25 percent for a yield of 5.56 percent and up from the close on Wednesday at 102.86.
"September Bunds are looking steady here and 103.00 is now the only key barrier protecting the 103.14/15 congestive region," MMS International said in a market commentary.
MMS said the market's recovery from 102.17 has been "impressive", market sentiment was good and a push above 103.15 would open the way for a move toward 103.53.
A key factor driving the market has been the U.S. long bond breaking thge 6.5 percent yield barrier and posting more gains.
And investors have been apparently deserting the long end of high-yield European debt in favour of hard-core markets such as Germany, which has been a factor in the recent gains.
But some traders are concerned the German market cannot keep pace with the U.S. amid lingering fears the Bundesbank may opt to raise rates to help shore up the currency.

Still, Bear Stearns said in a market commentary that the German yield curve will continue to flatten, particularly in the spread between two-year and 10-year debt that has broken below the key psychological level of 200 basis points and could soon test 175 basis points in the next one to two months.
